![Bulgaria: 63% of Transactions in Bulgaria are made in Cash](https://www.novinite.com/media/images/2022-04/photo_verybig_214573.jpg)

**Bulgaria** is second in Europe after Romania in the number of **cash** payments, according to statistics from ‘Global Findex’. In our country, 63% of transactions are made with **cash**, and in our neighbor - over 78%. Although the pandemic was expected to increase the digitalization of **money** and minimize physical **cash** and its applicability, data show that consumers in Europe still prefer **cash** payments.

**European countries in which **cash** transactions are predominant are:**

1. Romania

2. **Bulgaria**

3. The Czech Republic

4. Ukraine

5. Hungary

6. Slovakia

7. Greece

With over 70% and 63% of the total number of **cash** transactions, Romania and **Bulgaria** are the countries with the highest need for physical **money** in Europe. Also, 42% of the population of Romania and 28% of the population of **Bulgaria** do not have a bank account - this is indicative of the dependence of local consumers on physical banknotes and coins.

Other European countries are on the other financial pole, such as Norway, where only 3% of transactions are made in cash. Also, this country has an impressively low number of ATMs - only 32 per 100,000 population, but still 100% of adults in the country have a bank account.

*“In **Bulgaria**, and in Europe, there is a strong attachment of consumers to **money** and **cash** payments. Our expectations are that **cash** will survive the digital revolution and that people will continue to use it for many years to come as their preferred payment method,”* said Kalina Stoykin, Regional Manager of Euronet in **Bulgaria**, one of the largest payment companies in the world.

Euronet recently launched a large-scale campaign in **Bulgaria**, aimed at creating quick and easy access to **cash** in remote areas in Bulgaria. The **ATM** for the Community initiative is designed specifically for municipalities that want to offer **cash** withdrawals to their residents. More information about the project can be found [**here**](https://www.euronetatms.bg/%d1%80%d0%b5%d1%88%d0%b5%d0%bd%d0%b8%d1%8f-%d0%b1%d0%b0%d0%bd%d0%ba%d0%be%d0%bc%d0%b0%d1%82%d0%b8/%d0%b0%d1%82%d0%bc-%d0%b7%d0%b0-%d0%be%d0%b1%d1%89%d0%bd%d0%be%d1%81%d1%82%d1%82%d0%b0/).

1. **Cash** payment is satisfactory

A [**study**](https://cashessentials.org/coffee-tastes-better-when-paid-with-cash/) conducted by Prof. Avni M. Shah shows that paying in **cash** is a way to add positive emotion to transactions, which promotes cost satisfaction.

2. **Cash** makes us sensible buyers

Using **cash** helps to avoid impulsive purchases. A study of consumer psychology conducted among thousands of households shows that people who pay in **cash** spend less and have a larger share of health products in their basket.

3. **Cash** brings security

ATMs are a technique and as such can break down or run out of cash. At such times, the availability of physical **cash** will ensure trouble-free shopping.

4. Cache helps with budgeting

Paying in **cash** helps to avoid overspending while shopping. Carrying a certain amount acts as a brake for consumers to spend extra when their wallet is empty.

# China's graphite dominance threatens electric car market

A rise in demand for electric cars is boosting demand for graphite, a key battery component. As battery and car makers try to secure supplies, China's domination of the graphite market has become a problem.

![A worker covered in graphite dust at a warehouse where graphite is processed]( "A worker covered in graphite dust at a warehouse where graphite is processed")

Ripples of last year's power crunch in China are still being felt by global battery and electric-car makers.

A shortage of coal supplies caused by an Indonesian export ban, a trade war with major supplier Australia and a steep rise in post-COVID-19 domestic demand prompted local Chinese authorities to ration power to energy-intensive industries, including graphite.

The rolling power blackouts as well as the suspension of graphite production in winter further squeezed global graphite supply, already struggling to keep up with strong demand for lithium-ion batteries as [global electric vehicle sales went through the roof.](/en/tesla-posts-sales-of-almost-1-million-cars-in-2021/a-60313972)

As a result, the mineral, which has often been overlooked when it comes to battery materials, has added to the troubles of battery and car manufacturers, who have been scouring the planet to secure supplies of other battery constituents like lithium, nickel and cobalt.

The supply squeeze, which has driven up graphite prices, has yet again turned the focus on the global overreliance on China for graphite, the biggest component in lithium-ion batteries by volume with few viable alternatives.

![Electric car getting charged]()

China dominates the global graphite market, producing almost all of the graphite that's used for anode, the negative end of a lithium-ion battery.

"We hardly have any supply in Europe to even scratch the surface of future graphite demand for the lithium-ion battery industry so far," Burkhard Straube, the head of the graphite solutions unit at SGL Carbon, told DW.

"Without the further development of a European battery value chain including raw materials and components I would be highly concerned how companies in Europe as well as in North America would satisfy the demand for instance for graphite in the future," he told DW.

## Graphite shortfall

Graphite is a crystalline form of carbon. It is an excellent conductor of heat and electricity and is chemically inert with high thermal resistance and lubricity. These properties make the mineral almost irreplaceable in a vast array of industries ranging from semiconductors to nuclear reactors. It is an abundant mineral around the world but is also produced synthetically.

The demand for graphite has received a major boost from the auto industry that is undergoing a transition to electric vehicles (EV), powered by lithium-ion batteries, for now.

Tens of millions of EVs are expected to hit the roads in the next decade as part of global net-zero carbon pledges, driving a fivefold increase in demand for anodes by 2030, according to BloombergNEF. Graphite producers are unlikely to meet the massive demand at the current rate of production.

# How much do school teachers earn in Germany?

DW reports on how much German teachers earn and how they work, as well as how to become a teacher in Germany.

![German school]( "German school")

In Germany, if flowers or small gifts are given to school teachers, it's usually at the end of the school year, not at the beginning. In general, giving gifts to teachers is not common practice. And for those who still want to do so, they should be cautious. The fact is that school teachers are considered public sector employees (Öffentlicher Dienst) and are not allowed to accept expensive gifts, even on holidays. The federal states decide on the maximum value of gifts individually. In Berlin, for example, joint gifts from students worth more than 30 euros are not prohibited, but gifts worth more than that require reporting to the school administration.

Teachers should decline gifts worth more than 50 euros, as these require approval from the city's education department. There is also a list of [prohibited gifts](/ru/zapretnye-podarki-v-nemeckih-skolah/a-19518087): plane tickets, gift certificates, travel discounts.

## How to become a teacher in Germany

In Germany, teachers are trained for primary and secondary schools, as well as for high schools (Gymnasien). Those who want to teach in high schools attend a university, not a university of applied sciences (Fachhochschule). There, they learn scientific teaching methods and thoroughly study their subjects.

In Germany, a teacher teaches two subjects in school at the same time. Combinations can vary: geography and art, mathematics and literature. During their studies, future teachers take two state exams - Erstes Staatsexamen and Zweites Staatsexamen. Between them, they must complete a school internship (Referendariat), which lasts about a year and a half. Those who come from other countries with a teaching degree will have to validate their diploma and take additional courses to teach another subject.

![Teacher in a mask]()

## How much do teachers earn in Germany

A teacher's salary in Germany depends on the federal state, the presence of a civil servant status (Beamter), and the type of school where they work. For example, a high school teacher earns more than a primary school teacher. [In any case, teachers earn a salary above the national average.](/ru/сколько-получают-учителя-в-германии/a-50184414)

According to the Gehalt.de portal, with a 40-hour workweek, this is approximately 3,000 to 5,000 euros per month gross. In addition to a good salary, the status of a civil servant provides many benefits and a higher pension. Teachers without German citizenship cannot become civil servants.

## Shortage of primary school teachers

The profession of a teacher in Germany is definitely [promising](/ru/где-хотят-работать-молодые-немцы/a-19510358). According to statistics, due to the baby boom in German families and the influx of migrants, several hundred new primary schools will have to be opened in the coming years. Meanwhile, according to the German Teachers' Union (Deutsche Lehrerverband), the country is already lacking tens of thousands of specialists. For now, this problem is being addressed at the regional level in various ways - for example, by combining classes.

In German schools, there are significantly more female teachers than male teachers. If we take the statistics for 2019-2020, the share of women among teachers in German primary schools was 89.39%, and in high schools - 60.46%.

## How to become a teacher without special education

Due to the shortage of teachers in Germany, it has become possible to become a teacher even without a special diploma. For example, people with a master's degree in technical or humanitarian sciences can practice in schools and take additional pedagogical courses at the same time. In 2017 alone, 4,400 such specialists were hired in German schools. Teachers without a teaching diploma can earn around 2,900 euros per month before taxes.

# Energy Transition Is the "Dark Doldrums" a Threat in Winter?

Status: 07.03.2021 08:39 Uhr

**Germany is gradually phasing out nuclear and coal power. But what happens when the country is only supplied with renewable energy: What if neither the sun shines nor the wind blows?**

When it gets cold and dark in winter, Germans consume more electricity than usual: heating systems, lights, and televisions are used more when people stay indoors. So far, so normal. But this could become a problem, warns Professor Harald Schwarz from the Brandenburg University of Technology Cottbus.

Because when it's dark, no solar power is produced: "Then photovoltaic production is de facto zero, even though we have installed solar panels with 50 gigawatts of capacity in Germany." If there is no breeze at the same time, wind power also largely fails. "We're talking about 2 to 5 gigawatts of actual capacity, even though plants with 60 gigawatts of capacity have been installed," Schwarz specifies. What arises is the so-called "cold dark doldrums."

## Will "Day X" Become a Serious Problem?

The horror scenario is an extreme situation that theoretically only occurs on a few days a year. But these "Days X" could decide in the future whether the energy transition with the nuclear and coal phase-out will succeed. Because until now, Germany could always rely on its conventional power plants in an emergency - mainly from coal and nuclear power.

But precisely these power plants will be shut down in the coming years. According to Schwarz, Germany is threatened with a classic "power gap" - even if only on a few days. "Already in 2023, we will be missing 15 to 20 gigawatts of secure capacity," says Schwarz - and that will become a problem on a "Day X."

In the following years, the problem will worsen - because the nuclear phase-out is immediately followed by the gradual phase-out of coal-fired power generation. And power storage facilities are not yet able to solve the problem. "Today, we have capacities that can supply Germany for 30 to 60 minutes, but not for a prolonged dark doldrums," warns Schwarz. That means: power generation and power consumption must be identical every minute.

## The Federal Network Agency Calculates Differently

Until three years ago, Germany had the rule: the "secured generating capacity" must always be able to cover the maximum power demand. In other words: it must always be clear that there is enough power available, even in extreme cases. That's no longer the case. The Federal Network Agency, responsible for supply security, calls this calculation method outdated.

Instead, they now calculate the probability of such a case occurring. The result of the "stress test": on average, the complete power supply is not guaranteed for just 40 minutes a year. But even then, the lights in Germany won't simply go out: "During this time, the majority of the load can be covered, only a very small part may not be served by the market," emphasizes the Federal Network Agency.

## Agency Relies on Multiple Emergency Mechanisms

The "very small part" refers to a few large industrial plants that would be temporarily disconnected from the grid - such as aluminum smelters. These major consumers have agreements in place to reduce their power consumption in emergency situations. With these mechanisms, the Federal Network Agency is confident that the power supply can be maintained even in extreme cases.

# Europe wants to make building materials more sustainable

April 10, 2024

![Europe wants to make building materials more sustainable](https://assets.nationbuilder.com/groen/pages/18656/attachments/original/1712762311/Persbericht_zonder_foto_parlementslid_%2810%29.png?1712762311)

"To accelerate the use of sustainable and safe building products, this law sets a higher standard for our product standards. A good thing that leads to a climate and environmental policy that protects both humans and the planet, and provides a level playing field for our businesses."

**The European Parliament has just voted on a law to make building products more sustainable and improve reuse. The impact of the construction sector on the climate and environment is enormous. That's why the law is, according to [Sara Matthieu](/sara-matthieu), who was the rapporteur in the Environment Committee, an essential building block of the European Green Deal: "To accelerate the use of sustainable and safe building products, this law sets a higher standard for our product standards. A good thing that leads to a climate and environmental policy that protects both humans and the planet, and provides a level playing field for our businesses."**

**Only 1% of building materials are reused**

The impact of the construction sector is enormous. It is responsible for half of all raw materials used in Europe, produces 35% of all waste in the EU, and consumes a third of the total European water consumption. The construction sector is responsible for 36% of the total greenhouse gas emissions in the EU. That's more than the total emissions of the African continent. Matthieu: "Intervening in the sector can bring us many environmental and climate benefits. Moreover, only 1% of all building products are reused, partly due to a lack of standards and product norms that facilitate dismantling and reuse. That needs to change urgently, and with this law, we are taking an important step. We are stimulating the growth of innovative companies in the sector."

**Steps forward**

We are making progress in terms of sustainability. For the first time, the law prescribes a specific approach to the environmental impact of products through new product standards. Matthieu: "Manufacturers will have to disclose the impact of their building products, such as insulation materials, roofing and flooring, or doors and windows, ranging from climate to toxicity for humans and nature. This information will also be made available through a digital product passport. This makes it easier for companies, and where relevant also for consumers, to compare different materials."

**Repair instead of replace**

We are also giving the European Commission the possibility to require manufacturers to provide spare parts at an affordable price and a reasonable delivery time, for example for window frames.

# Two thirds of Poles oppose adoption of the euro, poll shows

Share

According to a survey released over the Easter weekend an overwhelming majority of Poles oppose entry into the common-currency Eurozone, preferring to keep the Polish złoty.

A poll conducted by the United Surveysagency for news portal *Wirtualna Polska* (*WP*)found that 67 per cent of respondents were against any attempt to replace the złoty with the euro, with 27 per cent backing the idea.

Adoption of the common currency was opposed by 52 per cent of voters who, at the last elections, supported parties that now form the Government led by Prime Minister Donald Tusk. Just 37 per cent of pro-Government voters were willing to consider ditching the złoty.

[![]()](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=earrcf0O9Ls&t=7s)

The strongest opposition to the introduction of the euro was from voters who backed the Conservatives (PiS) or the right-wing Confederation party at the last elections, with 95 per cent against adopting the common currency.

The parties that make up the ruling coalition – the Civic Coalition led by Tusk, the Third Way alliance and the Left party – are in favour signing up for the common currency but have indicated there would be no such move any time soon.

Finance minister Andrzej Domański stated in March that Poland has not, as yet, met the criteria for joining the ERM II mechanism pegging the złoty to the euro for a period before the European bloc’s currency is officially adopted.

Both the PiS and Confederation are opposed to Poland adopting the euro, citing what they said were negative experiences for southern Europe and price rises in neighbouring Baltic states and Slovakia.

The governor of Poland’s central bank (NBP) Adam Glapiński has said he would not support any such move until the Polish GDP per head was around that of Germany’s. He is currently facing an attempt to oust him by the Tusk Government over an alleged failure to control inflation.

Membership of ERM II requires Glapiński and Domański to apply to the European Central Bank, proposing a fixed rate of the złoty to the euro, requiring the Polish central bank to maintain that set value with only 15 per cent variations either way.

(PiS) MP Zbigniew Kuzmiuk told *Brussels Signal*: “The attempt to oust Glapiński has been caused by his staunch opposition to making any moves towards adoption of the euro, which he is capable of blocking as joining the ERM II mechanism is not possible without consent of a country’s central bank.”

The PiS also pointed to the fact that the Polish Constitution would need to be changed for the złoty to be replaced by the euro and to do that a two-thirds majority in favour in Parliament would have to be secured.

Poland joining the ERM II mechanism would be possible as long as the head of the central bank consented.

Adopting the European common currency was part of Poland’s European Union accession treaty, although no deadline for doing so was agreed.

The previous Tusk-led government (2007-2015) considered such a move but backed out amid the financial crisis of 2008. The then-finance minister Jacek Rostowski persuaded Tusk that Poland retaining the złoty was a useful tool enabling devaluation to avoid a deep recession.

Poland’s political parties are currently occupied by elections at the regional, municipal and county levels on April 7. Campaigning for the European Parliament elections in June is yet to begin.

The fact that Poles continue to oppose adopting the euro will likely become a focus of the PiS campaign in the European elections, while it will probably be an issue the ruling coalition would prefer to side-step.

As the publication notes, the "overwhelming majority of deputies" during this discussion supported the proposal of the European Commission to transfer bank profits from these assets to military aid to Ukraine.

However, this refers specifically to the accrued interest on those Russian deposits that are stored in Europe. "Many parliamentarians insist that this is not enough. They cited various arguments in favor of confiscating the entire amount of Russian assets to support Ukraine – approximately 300 billion euros, of which about 220 billion are in the European Union," DW writes.

The European Parliament's special rapporteur on Russia, Andrius Kubilius, emphasized that such confiscation would be entirely legitimate, as international law and UN recommendations give states the right to apply countermeasures to force an aggressor to fulfill its legal obligations.

Kubilius recalled that the United States had resorted to such actions with state funds of Iran in 1981 and Iraq in 1992 to compensate for the damage caused to Kuwait. And now, after approval by Congress, the US administration will apply this mechanism to confiscate $20 billion in Russian assets frozen in the United States.

However, the pro-Russian lobby in the European Parliament insists that such confiscation is allegedly "piracy". In particular, this was stated by "independent" deputy from Slovakia Katarína Roth-Nevěďalová and two Irish parliamentarians from the Left Party, who usually take a pro-Russian position.

Closing the debate, the EU's top diplomat, Josep Borrell, assured that for now, the European Union is not going to confiscate the frozen assets of the Russian Central Bank, "because there is not enough clarity about what we can and cannot do". "Of course, we would be very happy if we could take these 300 billion euros," Borrell said. "We will continue to study this issue and seek legal assistance to understand what else is possible."

# Technology Openness Instead of Symbolic Politics – Against a General Speed Limit on Highways

![Highway](/sites/default/files/styles/image/public/2024-04/20240403_tempolimit-beitrag_1.png?itok=x7oLMK58)

## What We Free Democrats Stand For:

Instead of relying on bans, we focus on innovations and technological openness. We, the Free Democrats, strongly oppose a general speed limit on highways. For safe and climate-friendly mobility that is also affordable, we don't need a speed limit or a ban on internal combustion engines, but rather a well-maintained infrastructure network and intelligent traffic management. To reduce emissions, we rely on international emissions trading and innovative technologies such as intelligent guidance systems that help drivers avoid traffic jams and detours. This approach prevents congested traffic, which increases the risk of accidents and CO2 emissions.

## But Doesn't a Speed Limit Make Highways Safer and Help Reduce CO2 Emissions?

No, neither statement is entirely accurate. Highways in Germany are among the safest roads. We have a greater safety problem on rural roads. Moreover, there is no correlation between a general speed limit and increased safety on highways, even in international comparisons. Additionally, monotonous driving at a constant speed over long distances contributes to a higher risk of accidents. We must support innovative technologies and their development, which improve the safety of mobility. Guidance systems can also reduce traffic congestion and make it safer. Besides traffic safety, it is often claimed that speed limits have a positive impact on climate protection. A study commissioned by the FDP parliamentary group shows that a speed limit would only save 1.1 million tons of CO2 – at high economic costs. Instead of using inefficient symbolic measures and bans to protect the climate, we Free Democrats focus on innovations and new technologies for smooth and congestion-free traffic.

## Why We Support Emissions Trading:

To effectively combat climate change, we rely on the opportunities offered by modern technologies. Our goal must be to establish an international emissions trading system as quickly as possible. To achieve this, the global climate club must be expanded and supplemented by an agreement on a unified emissions trading system. Driven by economic incentives, emissions trading promotes innovative technologies, such as the use of climate-friendly engines and fuels.
